explanation:
For a sound determination of unreachable code in OS_FileSysStartVolume_Impl the analyzer needs the following additional symbols and why:

- OS_filesys_internal_record_t: defines all fields accessed (fstype, device_name, system_mountpt, volume_name) and their sizes. Required to decide whether branches that depend on fstype or buffer-size checks (mplen < sizeof(system_mountpt), memcpy bounds) can be taken or are impossible.

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET and OS_filesys_table: the macro/object that produces 'local'. Necessary to know whether local can ever be NULL or what initial values it may contain; affects reachability of all subsequent code that dereferences local.

- OS_POSIX_DEVICEFILE_PREFIX: value/length of this prefix is needed to evaluate the strncmp condition that changes fstype (determines whether the "normal disk" branch can be taken).

- OS_FILESYS_TYPE_UNKNOWN, OS_FILESYS_TYPE_NORMAL_DISK, OS_FILESYS_TYPE_VOLATILE_DISK: enumeration constants used in fstype comparisons and assignments; required to determine which conditional blocks are potentially executed.

- getenv: used to obtain TMPDIR in the VOLATILE_DISK handling; its semantics (possible NULL) affect whether tmpdir can be non-NULL and thus whether the tmpdir selection loop can succeed.

- stat and struct stat (and S_IWOTH, S_IWGRP, S_IWUSR): used to test existence and permissions of candidate tmpdirs. Needed to determine whether the loop can break (i.e., whether the volatile path is reachable) or always falls through.

- getegid, geteuid: used in group/owner checks on stat results; required to evaluate the permission expressions that guard breaking out of the tmpdir-selection loop.

- OS_strnlen: used to measure volume_name; its behavior and return bounds are needed when reasoning about the memcpy/termination logic and whether that branch is reachable or can overflow.

- snprintf and memcpy: the two string-manipulation functions used to build system_mountpt. Required to reason about the mplen < sizeof(...) check and subsequent memcpy — whether that code path can be taken or is impossible (unreachable).

- OS_DEBUG: called when no tmpdir is found; required to determine whether the error-reporting and subsequent return path is reachable.

- OS_FS_ERR_DRIVE_NOT_CREATED and OS_SUCCESS: the return codes used by the function; needed to determine reachability of the error return vs the final success return.

Together these symbols provide the type/layout, macro expansion, environmental/system-call behavior, constants and functions required to prove whether particular branches (especially the volatile-disk selection loop, permission checks, and buffer-copy branch) can ever be executed. Without them the analyzer cannot decide if those code regions are necessarily unreachable, or reachable under some runtime/environment conditions.
